This is alternate view for electronic stability of an atom. The forces that keeps an electron in its orbit are electric and magnetic. From classical view, an electron attracted to nucleus is electrostatic or electric force. It’s possible that there is only one kind of charge and its quantity in comparison defines positive and negative charge. Keeping this matter aside, so due to electric force from centre, a free moving electron tends to orbitting around the centre at a distance where electric force from centre called as centripetal force equals inertial force of an electron called as centrifugal force.

Though there is no force as an inertial force which keep redirecting it on a circular path, every motion comes to stop in absence of external force. So there is magnetic force develops at centre which also causes electron to spin so its magnetic moment account for orbitting. Due to any reason, if strength of central or electric force increases then an electron comes closer to centre. But its magnetic force also increases that encounters an electric force in opposite direction to prevent an electron to keep falling into nucleus. Speed of an electron remain same for different orbits of different radius, so cause of magnetic force only depends upon radius of orbit.

This is the mechanisms for an electron to keep orbitting and not fall into centre and also switching to different orbit and remain stable. The magnetic spin cause movement of an electron seen as inertial force and preventing an electron from collapsing into the centre. This explanation doesn’t need quantum theory which only account for result and not underlying mechanism.

When an object falls, it’s subjected to a force called as gravity. For common heights, gravity remains constant, otherwise it obeys inverse square law for distances.

Initially an object subject to force gains speed or accelerate, but soon it reaches a saturation beyond which it can’t gain speed for given conditions, this speed is callef terminal speed. The cause of terminal speed is entropy.

Yes, entropy inhibits further energy conversion to work done, which is gain of speed in this case. It is well known before theory of relativity that constant force can’t produce constant acceleration. But explanation given by theory of relativity is wrong because there is no mass gain but force is converting into keep an object at constant speed.

The term "Ultra-violet Catastrophe" was first used by Paul Ehrenfest in 1911 talking about the Rayleigh Jeans law from 1905 and his attempts from 1903 to 1906 to solve the blackbody radiation problem using classical physics , Planck's work is from late 1900, but Planck was aware of a first try from Rayleigh from early that year (in 1900). So the catastrophe was solved before it was discovered... It was more like the desperation from those who couldnt accept the new quantum approach of physics. Quantization always, always comes from boundary conditions.  Blackbody derivation is a boundary-condition problem.  Derivation follows closely Maxwell's wave equation solution of a waveguide resonator, with discrete allowable "modes." Wherever one sees "quantization" or "modes" in nature, one can be certain that "quantization" derived from boundary-conditions and didn't magically fall out of the sky (as the brilliance of Max Planck or otherwise).

Perhaps quantum mechanics isn't as magical as thought, it's just that there is a limited understanding of how it functions.
Is it necessary for the theory to suggest that photons and electrons do not exist at times, or exist in multiple places at the same time, maybe the theory is incomplete.
Even as a layman I can think of a few alternatives, like the particles travel through another dimension and we do not know how to detect them while they are moved in another direction within that dimension.
Perhaps they are traveling near the speed of light and experience some time dilation, which interferes with our ability to predict their location or speed because we are not compensating for the time dilation.
Perhaps they exist as binary objects with antimatter or particles of half charges which we can not directly detect, are the half charges in the same dimensional plane?
Or perhaps the particles with half charges simply do not react in a way we understand due to our limitations of working with full charges in all our testing equipment, theories and knowledge.
And then, of course, there is the Heisenberg uncertainty principle, as we can not see an electron we can not detect it's position, we are just guessing where it is until we actually measure it and voila, there it is, but we have now changed its state in order to detect it.
Any time someone suggests magical qualities my immediate reaction is to think they're lazy and don't want to do the work of developing a working theory.
I've seen a few magic tricks, some are pretty convincing, but I have never once thought it's truly magical. Even if I can't figure it out right away.

Is it really a probability cloud though? I've seen something like this before in physics, where we say, it defies intuition. But does it really? Our mathematical models and methods of measurement are only so accurate. Just because we can't measure exactly where an electron is at a given time doesn't mean it doesn't exist in a single location. It simply means our measuring of it is uncertain. Intuition would say it's there, we just have limitations. (Why pose wild explanations like the election is travelling back and forth through time?, What!?)
Seems like Physicists take their models for reality too much. For example, take the contrast between a tensed theory of time and a tense-less theory of time, (or A and B theories of time) Its makes sense mathematically to make Time a forth dimension, helps with the math, it makes modelling much easier as far as I understand (caveat).
But this mathematical trick seems then to be taken as reality by Physics popularizers. Then instead of having the universe be a physical object moving through time (Newton's Arrow) we have a four dimensional space-time block. Where past, present and future is equally real. This theory of time (B) seems to go against intuition and common sense. Which makes it sensational!
( Headline: Physics proves time travel is possible because past, present and future are equally real and existent! )
Science popularizers then jump on it for the sake of a riveting TV Doc. but does it really make sense and is there any evidence for choosing the theory that seems illogical, and defies all our experiences?
Just saying it is great that math/physics can reveal so much about the universe but take a second look before assuming it's really reality.

fun fact: "black" is cognate to the word "bright" and is also cognate to blanc, blanco, bianco (in French, Spanish and Italian respectively), all meaning "white". The word "blank" is also cognate with "black". The English word "white" comes from wheat, which is the color you get when you grind it to flour. The change in meaning is because when something glows bright it can end up charred, and thus it becomes the color of char.
The Old English word for Black was something like "sweart".

Great video! Actually, the "many worlds" interpretation of quantum mechanics is fairly intuitive. It's pretty much the only one that is sensible.
E.g. it's not that the electron gets locked down to a single position when you measure it, but you and your measuring equipment get "entangled" with the electron, so you only observe the electron at that specific location.
The electron still exists at its other possible locations, but you can't observe it.

Yet Another video that perpetuates a common misunderstanding that Max Planck explanation of Black Body radiation involved the quantization of radiation.

What Plank did was to produced an equation that fit the observations of Black Body radiation. That the Rayleigh–Jeans Equation had failed to do.

He then explained this equation by proposing that the 'Oscillators'  in the walls of  the Black Body could only absorb or emit light in whole packets or quanta.

 He did not proposed that the Radiation itself was 'quantized'

It was Einstein that proposed light traveled as quantized packets to explain the photo electric effect.

The term 'photon'   to describe these quantized packets of light was not used for several year later.

There's absolutely nothing wrong with the mathematical theory of classical physics. The mistake Rayleigh and Jeans made was to assume a blackbody exists in classical physics. Nothing would emit infinite energy; instead, the energy would just dissipate to higher and higher frequencies, never reaching a steady state. But we do see things in reality that look a lot like blackbodies. The conclusion is that the world is not classic. But the mathematical theory is still perfectly consistent. There is no "ultraviolet catastrophe" because in classical physics blackbodies don't exist.

This is crucial, because Planck seems to have been the only one that started with a finite amount of energy and then thought of how to distribute it through different vibrational modes to get the observed spectrum. Everyone else was starting with the wrong assumption that a blackbody had infinite energy. If you start with a finite amount of energy, it's easy to see that a blackbody can only exist if the energy is somehow quantized.
